poem:
**Burger Olympiad**

In Paris,
they hurdle and vault—
           strong sinewed leaps.
I watch, 
            knife in hand,
the balance of buns.
Tomato, lettuce, a pat of cheese.
How they strain,
for medals and fame.
I savor—
            my preparations,
one-layered ambitions.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "I know how to improve the Olympics. First up, the burger-stacking contest | Jay Rayner In a few days the Paris Olympics will begin. This should be a moment of true joy and excitement but, honestly, I’m not feeling it. This is because I find the whole sporting shebang terribly unrelatable. It’s about people who can jump high, throw things a long way or run fast. I can do none of these things; I haven’t". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
